source.329229a6:
def imshow(img, transform):
    """helper function to show data augmentation
    :param img: path of the image
    :param transform: data augmentation technique to apply"""
    
    img = PIL.Image.open(img)
    fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(15, 4))
    ax[0].set_title(f'original image {img.size}')
    ax[0].imshow(img)
    img = transform(img)
    ax[1].set_title(f'transformed image {img.size}')
    ax[1].imshow(img)

source.43e38c83:
#Hue can be described of as the shade of the colors in an image

img = PIL.Image.open('../input/watermarked-not-watermarked-images/wm-nowm/train/watermark/animal-pet-eyes-cat.jpg')
fig, ax = plt.subplots(2, 2, figsize=(16, 10))

# brightness
loader_transform1 = transforms.ColorJitter(brightness=2)
img1 = loader_transform1(img)
ax[0, 0].set_title(f'brightness')
ax[0, 0].imshow(img1)

# contrast
loader_transform2 = transforms.ColorJitter(contrast=2)
img2 = loader_transform2(img)
ax[0, 1].set_title(f'contrast')
ax[0, 1].imshow(img2)

# saturation
loader_transform3 = transforms.ColorJitter(saturation=2)
img3 = loader_transform3(img)
ax[1, 0].set_title(f'saturation')
ax[1, 0].imshow(img3)
fig.savefig('color augmentation', bbox_inches='tight')

# hue
loader_transform4 = transforms.ColorJitter(hue=0.2)
img4 = loader_transform4(img)
ax[1, 1].set_title(f'hue')
ax[1, 1].imshow(img4)

fig.savefig('color augmentation', bbox_inches='tight')
source.c18b2e4d:
# horizontal flip with probability 1 (default is 0.5)
loader_transform = transforms.RandomHorizontalFlip(p=1)
imshow('../input/watermarked-not-watermarked-images/wm-nowm/train/watermark/animal-pet-eyes-cat.jpg', loader_transform)

source.5bb2ee11:
Cats have some of the most unique eyes in the animal world: Instead of having circular pupils like humans, the black parts in the centres of their eyes are vertical - which can adapt quickly and can open and close like the aperture of a camera. 

The vertical pupil slits found in cats, snakes, and crocodiles also give these predators a competitive edge, by allowing them to better approximate their prey's distance by honing their depth perception and focus on the target.https://www.sciencealert.com/here-s-why-cats-have-such-weird-eyes
